description:
Our correspondent in Abuja is Will Ross, and he began by telling us why this is such a huge day for Nigeria.

"You gotta look back at the history of this country, and many Nigerians you speak to will say that their votes have never really counted in any of the previous elections. I mean the last contest was a better one in 2011 the most but there wasn't a real contest that the governing party was in control of all the things it needed in order to make sure that a huge majority came in for Goodluck Jonathon. But you gotta go back and look at rigged elections, coups, counter-coups, and it got to a stage where, you know, Nigerians really felt that their votes weren't really meaning anything. But this time they've actually proved that with some help from a very robust electoral commission, especially the head of the commission Attahiru Jega, they've proved that they can make a difference, and they can boot out a government if they are not happy with it."
